resource.chars: That they do not esteem her.
It seems that I am right
To be gay and cheerful,
Since Love inscribes, night and day,
A song in my heart,
Which reminds me of the good qualities of my lady.
Yes! I am right, by my soul,
And because of this I am so happy, I swear, that
My heart must rejoice and laugh
In joy; I can affirm this,
When I gaze at my sweet lady.
I must affirm, may God save me,
That in worth and honor she surpasses
Many women about whom much is often said.
God, who creates whatever he wants as is fitting,
With beauty, know this, did not
Give her less in comparison
To what her worth required.
This one can see clearly,
Whoever examines carefully,
How her sweet face looks,
And how it is so graceful, sweet God,
That nothing does me so much good
As to gaze into her bright face,
[Which is] fresh, of a rosy complexion.
And afterwards her very sweet little mouth,
Red like a cherry,
Which is so pleasantly positioned,
So tasty and amused,
That any lover must, with an eager heart,
Have the desire to approach
And to touch this tender mouth.
And also her joyful eyes,
From which a sweet gaze emanates,
For which reason I rightly want to look at her
And because of which anyone has difficulty preventing himself
From being struck, with no defense,
If he has his eye open and turned in that direction,
Because they are so gay and, in a very pleasant way,
Decorated with sweet deception.
Oh, God! I protected myself poorly from these eyes,
For, ever since they gazed at me,
Neither granary nor farm has been of use to me [to hide?],
For, truly, as I realize,
And as it has always seemed to me...
Stolen! Can this truly be true?
Yes! For moreover, truly,
I wish [?] that my heart would resolve
To be happy and strong in love,
Since my dear lady
Has such a sweet face, and a sweet expression,
That nothing is there except as one would wish,
Even though I am not describing fully
What I see there. A beautiful apparition
Love presents to me in the encounter.
At the first sight of her sweet face,
And the appearance of her noble body,
Which is so completely in conformity
That there is no man alive in the world,
If he knew how to look well,
Who would find something to reproach there,
So much is her body distinguished and alert.
Her beautiful, sweet eyes! And when the memory
Is in my heart of the design
Of such a sweet creature,
Whose face
Is like nothing in nature,
And with a body so distinguished and elegant
—And I see her noble and graceful attire—
That he is not transported away by this excess,
And I reconsider, next, the port
Of her noble body and her manner
Which is neither proud nor arrogant,
But rather simple, sweet and lovable,
And the port remains so appropriate
And she knows how to carry herself so well,
That there is no soul who sees her
When she goes down the road,
Who does not love her—because of which I esteem her.
Therefore, if Love has stolen or taken
My heart, through the gaze
Of such a woman, may God help me!
It is not fitting that I put on
A sad or astonished expression,
For why would I be anxious?
The fear that my heart has been lost
Has completely left me,
Even if it stays there forever,
Since Love wants me to remember
And remains in me a little bit.
Rather I say—may God govern me!—
That if until today
My heart was in great torment,
Wounded and pained by troubles,
Now it has risen and been lifted up,
And if it was ever lost,
It has now been found.
And it seems to me that I am right,
For my heart, in another period,
Before the arrow had touched it,
This arrow poisoned with fear,
Which has now taken root in me,
Was weak and miserable and knocked down,
Afflicted and mournful and almost dead.
But now, when I feel
The torments of sweet remembrance
Of the graceful appearance
Of my lady, from which all good comes to me,
Or when it happens through good luck
That I am able to see her in front of me,
Never again will a day come
When I do not feel stronger
And willingly apply myself
To doing and saying happy things,
In taking pleasure and enjoying myself,
Since my heart has been taken in this way,
By Love, it can only be
Joyful and gay;
And joy lives in it,
And makes me live joyfully,
Remaining joyful and gay.
Truly, I can well sing this time:
He decided to capture me joyfully,
Love, as you can hear:
Capture? Truly! He captured me well!
No man was ever taken so well,
This I can truly affirm,
For if it happens that a man is, because of debt,
Or because of some other misdeed,
Put into prison,
If his body is imprisoned,
Neither the knowledge that God gave him
To govern and conduct himself,
Nor his heart can be restrained.
But I am taken by a powerful master—
For I do not see how this is possible—
Lords, with none of the faculties that I have,
Or with my heart, which me pulls completely
Always, without my desire to stop it,
Towards the place where the arrow must have left
